question: Turn on the flashlight.
answer: I'm trying. It doesn't work.

question: It has to work. You just bought it this afternoon.
answer: Do they come with batteries?

question: You didn't buy batteries?
answer: I thought they came with batteries.

question: I can't believe you didn't check.
answer: I bought everything you put on the list. Gloves. Pen knives. Flashlight. Batteries were not on the list.

question: Why should I have to put it on the list? It's like saying to buy a car with tires. Let's go. Be careful it's... ... hot! Light your lighter. I can't see anything... and try not to burn down the house!
answer: Is he dead?

question: I don't know. He looks dead.
answer: He looked dead before he fell.

question: Start the car! Start the car!
answer: You didn't think to move the car before we came out!

question: I heard you almost got your ass blown off last night. Some thief. A regular black panther.
answer: A Black Panther was a member of an African American militant group in the sixties, Marcel. I think you're referring to The Pink Panther.

question: Pink panther, black panther. Who gives a shit? And I don't remember asking you a God Damn thing, you little turd.
answer: There's no reason to be abusive. You're projecting your anger on me as a defense mechanism.

question: What the hell is he talking about?
answer: I'm talking about human beings communicating openly and honestly.

question: I know someone. Going somewhere?
answer: Oh, Marcel! I thought you were somebody else. If I knew it was you I would have never run. You're probably here for the money I owe you. I don't have it. Marcel opens the door to the bathroom and pushes Sami inside. You know this is how rumors get started. Told you.

question: Today's your lucky day, Sami.
answer: Yeah, I can see that.

question: Normally I'd be breaking your fingers right now, but I'm going to give you a chance to make enough to pay me back and have some extra for yourself. We have a group going to Chicago to do a job. You're going with them.
answer: Me?

question: You lived there. You know the city.
answer: I've still got a few legal problems back in the States. But I'd be... I'd be happy to go.

question: I'm Sami. Marcel sent me.
answer: What is it you do, Sami?

question: You know, a little of this, a little of that. I've boosted cars, stole radios, run a few scams. Right now I'm into pick-pocketing.
answer: I see. A master criminal.

question: Where are you from?
answer: Algeria.

question: And you don't speak French?
answer: Well, you know, not all Algerians speak French. It's a matter of what school you went too. Me I never really --

question: We'll see.
answer: I thought I would accompany you to the airport to say bon voyage... and tell you that Marcel will be going with you.

question: What?
answer: This is a considerable move up for you, Daniel. The temptation of having so much money might be too much for you.

question: You don't trust me?
answer: I don't trust anyone. You don't get to the top of this game by trusting people... and after all, you are a thief. It's in your nature to steal. I'm just protecting my investment.

question: I am Raymond. Thank you for allowing us to stay here.
answer: No problem, man. Hey, you wanna hit?

question: No thank you. Oh, Pepe Le Pew. He is very funny and quite well known in France.
answer: Yeah, I dig him.

question: Although a cartoon I feel he shares a universal theme
answer: Whoa... That's deep.

question: I did not order escargot.
answer: They don't serve wine here.

question: What kind of restaurant doesn't serve wine?
answer: This kind.

question: I'm sorry, Frankie. Really.
answer: You bleed on me, I'll kill ya. What'd I tell you? Huh, Vinny? What'd I tell you when you came to me for money? Didn't I ask you not to do it? Did I not say that? What'd I say to him? That's right. I said don't do it. Did you listen to me? No. You wanted the money. So, I lent you twenty large. Now it's been three weeks and you ain't paid a dime. What do you think that makes me look like on the street? I don't do something to you and everyone will think they can skate.

question: Frankie, I --
answer: -- Shut up! Don't you try to make me feel bad about this. You knew what would happen to you if you didn't pay. This is on your head, not mine. Break his arm.

question: Jesus, Frankie, I'm your brother!
answer: That's why we're only breaking one arm.

question: Hey, Bobby beans... How you doin'?
answer: Good. I'm doing good. How you doin', Frankie?

question: Good. I'm good.
answer: Mr. Maranzano sends his warmest regards.

question: When you return please extend my regards to Mr. Maranzano and his family. Can I offer you something. A drink? Coffee?
answer: No thank you.

question: You sure? I just got a shipment of espresso from Sicily. Special blend. Can't find anything like it in the States.
answer: I'm good. Really.

question: Okay. I understand you're interested in one of our properties?
answer: Yeah. That warehouse over on Merchant Street. The volume on our import business has risen dramatically. The proceeds this quarter will be supernumerary due to the --

question: -- Super what?
answer: Supernumerary. It means better than expected.

question: Then why not just fuckin' say better than expected? Everybody knows what better than expected means.
answer: I'm taking a vocabulary course to enhance my communication skills.

question: Okay. How much?
answer: I'm not here to negotiate.

question: Why are you here?
answer: To tell you that we're interested in the property.

question: You told me that on the phone. What the hell are you doing here? Showing off your communication skills? Go back to your people and tell them when they're serious to put a number on the table.
answer: I will relay the particulars of our conversation to Mr. Maranzano.

question: You like shoes?
answer: No, I like the bag. It would be good for the job tonight.

question: It belongs to Vincent Bastaldi. He left it last time he was here. I'm sure he wouldn't mind if you used it. So, how did you get hooked up with these guys?
answer: Just lucky I guess. How'd you start working for the Bastaldi's?

question: The art world doesn't fully appreciate my talent yet. I needed some way to pay the rent. Laurant and Vincent pay well for information.
answer: So you arranged to have the people you worked for robbed?

question: They're not nice people. I like your tattoo. Casandra. Old girlfriend?
answer: Something like that.

question: Did she break your heart?
answer: Something like that.

question: It looks old. Did you get it a long time ago?
answer: You ask a lot of questions.

question: That's how you get to know someone. Did it hurt when you got it?
answer: I don't remember. I was drunk.

question: You got it in a bar?
answer: No. I got it in prison. I went in for three years. When I came out she was married to my best friend. Happy?

question: Sorry. I didn't mean to pry.
answer: It's okay. It was a long time ago.

question: I've been thinking about getting tattoo. You know, a flower or something. On my ass.
answer: Who's gonna see it there?

question: Yeah?
answer: Mr. B. wants to see you.

question: Now? I've got a date with a drop dead major babe.
answer: I'll tell him that.

question: Frankie, come in. Good to see you. You want something?
answer: No, I'm good, Angelo.

question: I understand Bobby Beans came to see you today.
answer: Yeah. Seems Maranzano wants to talk about buying the Merchant Street warehouse.

question: And?
answer: And nothing. He's just feeling us out.

question: He's trying to get a foot hold in our territory.
answer: He sticks his toes in the water again, we'll cut 'em off.

question: Business must be good if he can afford to buy up useless property.
answer: I heard this quarter his profits are gonna be supernumerary.

question: They're gonna be what?
answer: Supernumerary. It means better than expected.

question: Someone else coming?
answer: Nah, that's just Tony's way of telling me Judge Judy starts in ten minutes. You ever watch it?

question: Uh, no --
answer: You should. You can learn a lot about the criminal justice system on a program like that. Very informative. Stay and watch it with me.

question: You know, I'm kind of tired. I'm just gonna go home if it's all the same to you.
answer: Go. Rest. Oh Frankie, what's this I hear about your brother?

question: He missed three weeks.
answer: Your own brother? You couldn't send someone else to do it?

question: I did. Joey "Two Tons" and Nicky "The Rake" did the deed.
answer: But you were there?

question: Angelo, we live and die by the rules we make. We are men of honor, but honor without respect is a... horse-less carriage.
answer: What the fuck does that mean?

question: I'll be Elvis and you--
answer: -- I want to be Elvis.

question: It's my idea.
answer: C'mon, I look more like Elvis than you do.

question: Okay. You can be Elvis. And the rest of us are... John, Paul, George and Ringo.
answer: Hey, Barry Bonds. The home run king. It's for my nephew.

question: Hello?
answer: It's Elvis...

question: Who?
answer: It's me...

question: Yes.
answer: You're there now?

question: Oui.
answer: You're calling me on your cell phone, right?

question: No.
answer: You're calling me on is phone?

question: Oui.
answer: My number's going to show up on his bill!

question: Should I call you back?
answer: You've already robbed the safe?

question: Oui.
answer: Take what you've got and get out of there.

question: No, I didn't.
answer: Bastaldi got the address from you, yes?

question: Yes.
answer: And he gave it to us. 145 Ridgeway Road.

question: Someone stole my car tonight! You run a chop shop for low riders. Yes, I think you'd steal my car. And I should just believe--
answer: -- you stole my cousin Enrique's car.

question: Hector, don't interrupt me.
answer: He told Enrique he didn't know anything about his car.

question: Can't sleep?
answer: No.

question: I'm sorry things went so wrong today.
answer: It's not your fault.

question: What are you doing?
answer: I thought I'd listen to some of the tapes. See what's so important that a mob guy has to lock it away in his safe.

question: Sounds boring.
answer: It's three in the morning. Not much else to do.

question: Vincent Bastaldi is in jail.
answer: For what?

question: Laurant and Vincent were in business with Zammito.
answer: What kind of business?

question: This is turning to shit. If word gets out of my involvement in this I'll go to prison.
answer: Listen, we know their names. They don't know the city. You'll find them. You're the FBI.

question: I can't bring the Bureau into this. If I do the tapes become evidence.
answer: They're supposed to be evidence. That's why Bastaldi set this up.

question: Fuck Bastaldi and his brother. These tapes are gold. Do you have any idea what Zammito would pay to get them back?
answer: I thought you wanted Zammito?

question: What for? The minute I get him some other Gavone will take his place. I've been doing this for twenty years. When I retire it's not going to be to some trailer park in the suburbs. Too many people know about my involvement in this.
answer: Then we just have to make sure everyone who knows can't say anything.

question: I'll be right back. He gets out of the car and walks over to him.
answer: What do you want now?

question: Guns. Can you get them?
answer: Man, I can get anything.

question: Don't bullshit me.
answer: I ain't bullshittin'. I can get guns. I can get any kind of gun you want. But they ain't gonna help your sorry ass. You ain't been in town one day and already you got two of the toughest people in Chicago looking for you. How is that possible?

question: I've got a way with people.
answer: I can see that. The man's car you stole. Raphael Ruiz. He's head of the 19th Street gang and one crazy motherfucker. And Frankie Zammito's got the word out he's looking for some French dudes. You're French ain't ya?

question: I'm from Belgium.
answer: Yeah, I'd be from Belgium too if I was you. You know Zammito just put his own brother in the hospital? Broke his arm cause he was late on a debt. I mention this to illustrate the kind of people who are lookin' for you.

question: Why haven't you turned us in?
answer: I ain't no rat. You got money, right? And, uh, I'm going to have to charge you a commission... kind of like a brokerage fee.

question: How much?
answer: A thousand dollars?

question: Yeah? Hey dude, what do you think you're doing? Uh... excuse me, but don't you need a warrant or something?
answer: Not today. Where are your friends?

question: They left about a half hour ago.
answer: Where did they go?

question: I dunno. Hey man, you can't do that!
answer: What? This? Or this?

question: Jesus. What kind of FBI agent are you?
answer: I'm your worst fuckin' nightmare. Now, if you don't want me to keep on hurting you, it's important that I believe you and right now I don't. So tell me, where did they go?

question: This is bad. This is really fuckin' bad. Am I the only one who sees how bad this is?
answer: Hey, it's not your picture on the TV, it's mine. So, try to be cool.

question: Don't tell me to be cool! We were supposed to be in and out. In and out! In the last twenty four hours we've managed to get the Mafia... the FBI... the Chicago Police Department and a group of Latin gang members after us. I haven't left out anyone, have I? I don't think so, because we've already pissed off everyone in the fuckin' city!
answer: We've got to get out of here.

question: That's brilliant! Care to elaborate?
answer: You're not helping.

question: Yeah?
answer: It's me.

question: Hey you guys are becoming famous. I was just watching the news and--
answer: -- Did you set it up?

question: Yeah. All set. Tomorrow morning. Ten o'clock. Room 211. Barclay Hotel on River Street. Oh, and due to your recent notoriety and the heat that comes with it, I'm going to have to increase my brokerage fee to twenty five hundred.
answer: We had a deal.

question: We had a deal before you and your friends became the new poster boys for crime.
answer: Fine. Ten o'clock.

question: Why didn't you tell me about this?
answer: You have enough to worry about, Angelo. You don't need my problems.

question: We're family. An insult to you is an insult to me. They knew who you were when they broke in your house?
answer: Yes.

question: What is happening with the world? There was a time no civilian would touch a made man. Now every babbo in the world thinks he can get away with something. What did they take?
answer: Some cash. Jewelry. The other stuff I can replace, but there's a cardboard box... photos of my mother. They're the only ones I have of her.

question: We'll save you the trouble. What's wrong with this guy?
answer: He's my cousin. He's deaf.

question: We're here to buy, not steal. If you guys are straight there's not going to be a problem.
answer: Let them in. What can I do you for?

question: How much for the nines?
answer: A grand a piece.

question: Zammito's offering twenty grand a head for these guys. You think I'm going to settle for four G's when I can make forty? All right. Reach in easy and put the gun on the floor. I said put it on the floor, not kick it under the bed. Get that and add it to my inventory. I assume you're carrying too? Okay, put it on the floor... and do not kick it under the fuckin' bed.
answer: No.

question: No? Did you just say no? Listen cowboy, if you're thinking about makin' a move, don't. Nobody is that fast.
answer: Zero is.

question: Angie, how you doin'? Hey, you're looking good. There's something different about you. You get a boob job or something? Yeah, well, it suits you. Hey Tommy. Whatever. Angie, take the kids down to the gift shop and buy 'em something. I need a word with Vinny. She seems pleasant enough.
answer: She doesn't know. She thinks I fell down the stairs.

question: That's good. That's what a stand-up guy does. So, I just come by to see how you're doin'?
answer: You broke my arm. How the hell do you think I'm doin'?

question: Yeah. I mean besides that. They treating you all right? Food okay?
answer: Yeah. I'm going home today. What do you want, Frankie?

question: I don't want anything.
answer: A little?

question: Yeah. I mean, you are my brother and... well I should have found another way of expressing my disappointment. So, I've decided to make it up to you.
answer: You gonna forget about the money I owe you?

question: You set me up, you piece of shit! What are you doing?
answer: You think I'm going to talk to you until I know if you're wired.

question: Wired? I ain't wired.
answer: Okay. Okay. I believe you.

question: You killed her!
answer: No. You killed her. Manager remembers you going into her room. Your fingerprints were found all over the place.

question: Bullshit! She was alive when we left her with you.
answer: You're fucked, Sami. You know it. That's why you're here.

question: Look, I just want out of this nightmare. I don't know these guys. A few days ago I'm in Paris picking pockets and now I'm America's most wanted.
answer: Where are the tapes?

question: I can get them -- but what do I get if I do?
answer: A pass.

question: A pass? How you gonna give me a pass? A witness can put me at the crime scene.
answer: Witness' can be convinced they made a mistake. Without the murder weapon the D.A. won't have enough to prosecute you.

question: They don't have a murder weapon?
answer: No. I have it. The lamp? The one with your fingerprints and her blood on it? Remember? Of course they could always get an anonymous tip. Find it in the dumpster behind the motel.

question: You want the tapes for yourself. You're going to sell them.
answer: I'm going to retire with a shit-load of money. Find me a small country that doesn't have an extradition treaty with the States and live the good life.

question: You didn't have to kill Sophie.
answer: Yes I did. Lose ends are messy.

question: What about me? Aren't I a loose end?
answer: When this is over you can say whatever the hell you want. I'll be long gone. Besides, who's going to believe you? You're just a two-bit crook.

question: And you're a dirty cop. At least I don't pretend to be something different than what I am.
answer: When you've got the tapes call me on this number. We'll make the exchange and that'll be the end of it.

question: What's he joking around for? He's been shot.
answer: He's been shot a lot. He's used to it.

question: Anybody hungry?
answer: What'd you get?

question: Some bread and... Cheese.
answer: Cheese? In a can?

question: The new Beaujolais' come out in France next week. You like wine?
answer: I'm more of a whiskey drinker myself.

question: J&B?
answer: Glenmorangie.

question: Glenmorangie is very good.
answer: But I'll have a glass of Beaujolais with you when we get back.

question: But I'll have a glass of Beaujolais with you when we get back.
answer: I'll be back in an hour.

question: What?
answer: Can I trust you, Sami?

question: Hey, who warned you that they were coming up to the room?
answer: If they had taken us by surprise they would have gotten the tapes back. That would have left us with nothing.

question: No, that would have left me with nothing because all of you would be dead.
answer: You haven't answered my question.

question: Does it really matter what I say?
answer: I'm leaving you with my friends. I'm trusting you to do the right thing today.

question: I will.
answer: You better.

question: You better.
answer: Yeah?

question: I would like to see Mr. Bonanno please.
answer: Who the hell are you?

question: Tell him I'm the guy who robbed Frankie Zammito.
answer: In there.

question: I've got to tell you, Mr. Bonanno, This guy's an idiot. How he's lived this long is a mystery.
answer: I don't think it will be a mystery much longer.

question: He's recorded every conversation he's had with you for years.
answer: I assume you want something?

question: We've got a lot of people looking for us. We'd just like to go home.
answer: You want me to help you get out of the country? And for my help I would get what?

question: Half the tapes.
answer: And the other half?

question: I'll destroy them when we get back to Paris.
answer: I only have your word for that.

question: I just want to get my people home. I know who you are and what you could do to me if I don't honor my word.
answer: Where are you staying? I only ask so I can call you when the arrangements are made.

question: Since we're such good pals I thought I'd sneak you an advanced copy of my latest work. I call it, "I am a scum-sucking FBI agent". You want the tapes for yourself. You're going to sell them.
answer: I'm going to retire with a shit-load of money. Find me a small country that doesn't have an extradition treaty with the States and live the good life.

question: You didn't have to kill Sophie.
answer: Yes I did. Lose ends are messy.

question: Mr. Zammito?
answer: Uh huh.

question: I represent a person who wishes to remain anonymous, but is aware of your current financial problems with your brother.
answer: I don't know what you're talking about.

question: I understand. The person who sent me wishes to help you.
answer: How?

question: You see that car?
answer: Yeah.

question: It's yours. A gift. A gift you could give to your brother... or anyone you owe money to as partial payment.
answer: No shit?

question: Those the tapes? Watch the paint.
answer: The money?

question: How'd you get these?
answer: I got 'em. That's all you need to know.

question: What's this?
answer: A car.

question: Oh really? Thanks. I thought it was a sewing machine. What the hell is it doing here?
answer: It's for you.

question: For me? What am I going to do with a piece of shit like this?
answer: I don't know. Sell it. It's gotta be worth something. Someone gave it to me. C'mon Frankie, I'm trying to make good here.

question: Okay. Okay.
answer: I'll get you the papers tomorrow.

question: Anybody know about that car outside?
answer: Yeah. It's mine.

question: No. It's mine.
answer: The hell it is.

question: I'm telling you that's my car! And someone's gonna pay for it!
answer: And I'm tellin' you it ain't! Now, turn your taco-eating ass around and get the hell out of here.

question: Fuck you, grease-ball!
answer: Fuck me? Fuck you!

question: Hello?
answer: It's Daniel.

question: Daniel. Listen I'm afraid there has been a big--
answer: -- I've got the tapes. If you ever want to see your brother out of jail do exactly what I say. Bring one million euros to your boat at six o'clock.

question: A million! I don't have that kind of money.
answer: Don't bullshit me, Laurant! I know about the Van Gogh.

question: I don't have it. That's why Vincent went to Chicago. They arrested him before he could bring it back.
answer: Well, you better get the money somehow. Six o'clock and come alone. If you don't we'll destroy the tapes. Go back on deck. There's a small rowboat in the water -- Put the money in the rowboat and untie it. The current will carry it down river. When we see that the money is there I'll call back and tell you where the tapes are.

question: I'm sorry! I was caught up in the excitement of the moment. I should have checked. I made a mistake. I suppose that none of you have ever made a mistake before?
answer: This is great. After everything we've been through we've got eight hundred euros and an autographed baseball.

question: The baseball is mine.
answer: No! You can't have the baseball! You're not entitled to the fuckin' baseball!
